payload.title: Arriving at IST
payload.description: Istanbul Airport (IST) is on the European side. The new **M11 Metro** is now fully operational, offering a fast, traffic-free link to the city center (Gayrettepe/Kağıthane).
payload.criticalAlert: Do not take a taxi for long distances during rush hour (08:00-10:00 & 17:00-20:00). You will sit in traffic for 2+ hours. The Metro or the **Havaist Shuttle** are significantly more reliable.
tips: **Istanbulkart:** You need this card for the Metro and Ferries. Buy it at the yellow 'Biletmatik' machines in the airport transport floor (Level -2).
**BiTaksi / Uber:** Use these apps to hail yellow taxis. It ensures your route is tracked and provides a price estimate, reducing the chance of 'scenic route' overcharging.
**Sabiha Gökçen (SAW):** If landing at SAW (Asian side), use the M4 Metro line or the Havabus shuttle to Kadıköy.
**The Walk:** Note that the M11 Metro station at IST requires a 10-15 minute walk from the arrivals hall. Follow the 'U' (Ulaştırma) signs.

payload.title: Cash, Cards & Lira
payload.description: Due to high inflation, prices in Lira (₺) fluctuate rapidly. Cards are accepted in 95% of places, but 'Cash is King' for better bargaining in bazaars.
payload.criticalAlert: Avoid **Euronet ATMs** (blue/yellow kiosks) found in tourist areas. They charge extreme conversion fees. Only use official bank ATMs like **Ziraat Bankası, VakıfBank, or İş Bankası**.
tips: **Dual Pricing:** Many major sites (Hagia Sophia, Topkapi) now charge foreign tourists in **Euros (€)** or the Lira equivalent at a higher rate. Expect to pay ~€25-€30 for entry.
**Small Change:** Keep 5₺, 10₺, and 20₺ notes for tipping 'Bay' (public toilets) and street snacks like Simit.
**USD/EUR:** While some shops in the Grand Bazaar accept USD or EUR, you will always get a worse rate. Always pay in Lira.

payload.title: Safety & Common Scams
payload.description: Istanbul is generally safe, but its popularity makes it a hub for 'gentle' social engineering scams.
payload.criticalAlert: The 'Shoe Shine' Scam: A man will drop a brush in front of you. If you pick it up, he will offer a 'free' shine and then demand a high fee. Smile, keep walking, and do not pick it up.
tips: **The 'Let's Have a Drink' Scam:** Avoid solo men inviting you to a 'great bar' they know. You will end up with a bill for hundreds of dollars and a locked door.
**Mosque Etiquette:** Women must cover their heads and everyone must remove shoes. Most major mosques provide wraps for free at the entrance.
**Street Dogs/Cats:** They are community-owned and generally vaccinated. They are friendly but avoid getting too close to their faces while they sleep.
